scenes.title: Feeling trapped vs. values-aligned work
scenes.main_point: Avoid building a life that traps you in misaligned work; optimize for success plus meaning and values alignment.
scenes.scene_summary: I describe the fear of waking up late in my career feeling trapped by lifestyle and expectations, and I frame the goal as finding work that blends success with meaningful, values-aligned fulfillment.
key_elements: Sense of being trapped by lifestyle/expectations
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person stands before a mirror in a home hallway, seeing their reflection boxed in by symbols of lifestyle and expectations.
They hesitate, torn between career success and meaningful, values-aligned work, with an explicit trapped expression.

scenes.title: Curiosity Loops: fast structured advice gathering
scenes.main_point: Use a structured outreach to get contextual, high-signal input quickly.
scenes.scene_summary: I explain how I run a curiosity loop by sending a lightweight, specific question to a curated group, making it easy to respond, then processing the feedback and closing the loop with thanks so I can make smarter, more contextual decisions.
key_elements: Curate subject-matter experts + people who know me
Low cognitive load prompt (pick top 2–3 and why)
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A person at a desk types an email on a laptop to a small list of 10–11 recipients, with a clear, unbiased question and brief rationale on screen.
Nearby notes show “pick top 2–3 and why,” implying a low-effort reply request; the setting is a simple home office, mood focused.

scenes.title: Values exercise applied to real decisions
scenes.main_point: Clarify personal values to guide choices against external pressure.
scenes.scene_summary: I walk through a quick values exercise that turns a word list into a ranked set of guiding sentences, then I apply it to a real decision about what to say yes/no to, using values as an internal scorecard instead of chasing the external scorecard.
key_elements: Example values: adventure, optimism, generosity, improvement
Decision tension: more opportunities vs. doing less
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A presenter at a desk with a values word list on paper, crossing out words and arranging the remaining into a ranked stack with short guiding sentences.
In a simple office setting, they compare two columns labeled “yes/no” and “inner scorecard/outer scorecard,” looking focused.

scenes.title: Career growth: explore/exploit + hard skills practice
scenes.main_point: Early career is for exploration with a thesis; build skills by repeating discomfort until it becomes competence.
scenes.scene_summary: I outline how I navigated my early career by exploring roles and environments, then exploiting specific learning goals, and I emphasize ‘eating your vegetables’—repeating uncomfortable skills like networking or posting consistently until I’m genuinely good enough to judge whether I like it.
key_elements: Networking rule: hand out 10 business cards + touch back wall
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A young professional stands in a conference lobby, handing out business cards while stepping to the back wall, determined.
Nearby, a small whiteboard shows “Explore → Exploit” and “10–12 exposures / LinkedIn 30” as they practice uncomfortable skills.
